intro: Byrsonima cardenasii, commonly known as the Mexican black cherry, is a small to medium-sized tree native to Central America and northern South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its dark, aromatic bark and glossy, elliptical leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are followed by edible, cherry-like fruits. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates and is often found in lowland forests and along riverbanks. Its fruits are used in traditional medicine and as a source of food in some regions.
